BC-NYT-WORLD-BUDGET 
   Editors at publications outside the United States may find the
following stories from the New York Times News Service for
   WEDNESDAY, July 5,    of particular interest:

     INTERNATIONAL  

   (Will move in `i' news category)

   MEXICO-POLITICS (Mexico City) _ The Institutional Revolutionary
Party, which lost the presidency in Sunday's elections after more
than 70 years in power, will meet Tuesday to choose a new leader.
(Staff byline to come)

   With

   MEXICO-POLITICS-FOX (Mexico City) _ President-elect Vincente Fox
is scheduled to hold a press conference. By Ginger Thompson.

   CUBA-POLITICS (Havana) _ A top Cuban official, Ricardo Alarcon,
says in an interview that the government wants to capitalize on the
momentum created by Elian Gonzalez's return to Cuba to create
anti-U.S. embargo fervor. By David Gonzalez.

   RUSSIA-CHECHNYA (Moscow) _ Developments following the suicide
bombings of Russian military barracks by Chechen rebels. By Michael
R. Gordon.

   WORLD-BRIEFS (Undated) _ World news in brief.

     UNITED STATES    _ General

   (Will move in `a' category)

   SUMMER-SCHOOL (Undated) _ More students than ever before are
enrolled in summer school this season, as districts throughout the
country require or strongly encourage students to attend classes to
shore up basic reading and mathematical skills. But many are
worried that the programs will simply repeat ineffective
instructional approaches and frustrate struggling students with
endless drills for high-stakes exams. By Jodi Wilgoren.

   (This article is tentative and may be eliminated later.)

   NY-JULY4 (New York) _ On the July 4th Operation Sail
celebration, billed as the largest flotilla in history, and the
evening's fireworks display, billed as the largest ever in New
York. By Alan Feuer.

   BIKER-COPS (Undated) _ They are police officers by trade, but
their appearance, as a group, does not exactly shout law
enforcement.Maybe it is the tattoos and beards. Or the V-Twin
Harley cruisers equipped with shotgun dual exhausts and tuned to
scorch the road. Or maybe it is their name: The Wild Pigs. With
1,400 members in 80 chapters, the Wild Pigs are one of two
increasingly popular, national motorcycle clubs that draw their
members from the law enforcement ranks. By Kevin Flynn.

   SCI-ALZHEIMER (Undated) _ A new study reports that people with
advanced Alzheimer's Disease who break a hip or develop pneumonia
are likely to die within 6 months and should be kept comfortable
and spared painful medical procedures. By Denise Grady.

     BUSINESS  

   (Will move in `f' news category)

   JAPAN-ECON (Tokyo) _ Faced with fresh evidence that the economy
is accelerating, Japan's central bank could soon raise interest
rates, which have been at an effective rate of zero for more than a
year. Such a move would be the first rate increase in Japan in
nearly a decade. By Stephanie Strom.

   (An early version of this story will move by 3 p.m. EDT.)

   INTERNET-TELEPHONE (Undated) _ A look at Internet telephony, the
growing use of the Internet to make telephone calls, basically for
free. By Simon Romero.

   GERMAN-TELEKOM-SPRINT (Frankfurt) _ Deutsche Telekom has taken
some preliminary steps to make a bid for Sprint if its merger
agreement with WorldCom is scrapped. By Edmund L. Andrews and
Andrew Ross Sorkin.

   EUROPE-U.S.-MERGERS (London) _ The number and value of mergers
and acquisitions in Europe soared in the second quarter of the
year, and many of the target companies were in the United States.
By Andrew Ross Sorkin.

   KAZAKHSTAN-U.S.-OIL (Moscow) _ The head of Kazakhstan's
state-run oil company has denied allegations that he and other
Kazak officials accepted bribes from U.S. oil companies. By Sabrina
Tavernise.

   BRITISH-AIR-KLM (London) _ British Airways and KLM could lay off
as many as 6000 employees if their planned merger proceeds.
European regulators are also likely to require them to sell their
low-cost subsidiaries. By Andrew Ross Sorkin.

   WORKING-DOGS (Undated) _ There are dogs that work as actors and
guards; there are dogs that aid the blind, the deaf and the ill.
There are dogs that work for the police, sniffing out drugs, bombs
and missing bodies. Then there are racing dogs, rescue and show
dogs. There are dogs that herd cattle and sheep, and dogs that
serve as companions for patients in nursing homes and hospitals. Of
course, most dogs do duty as family pets, and that role should not
be made light of. By Fred Brock.

     ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS  

   (Will move in `e' news category or as indicated)

   WOMEN-ARTISTS-SEX (Undated) _ The media-genic artists of the
oughties _ as the current decade is sometimes called _ are often
women. And they are women who exude high levels of post-feminist
attitude and are as fearless about tackling sexual issues in their
own work as they are about using their sexuality _ or general
attractiveness _ whenever the media look in their direction.By
Roberta Smith.

   LYONS-BIENNIAL (Lyons, France) _ ``Sharing Exoticisms,'' the
name given to the Fifth Lyons Biennial of Contemporary Art,
features art from outside the Western world, or influenced by
non-Western cultures. By Alan Riding.

   TREVOR-NUNN-THEATER (London) _ Over the last few months, Trevor
Nunn, whose credits as director include ``Cats,'' ``Les
Miserables'' and ``Nicholas Nickleby'' and who headed the Royal
Shakespeare Company for 18 years, has come under considerable fire
in the London papers for his three-year-old stewardship of the
Royal National Theater. By Robin Pogrebin.

   NY-STREET-FOOD (New York) _ New York's love affair with European
street foods has grown, and this year I've found myself embracing
waffles, sausages, crepes and other tidbits that are combining the
aura of Old World style with American speed. By Eric Asimov.

   (Will move in `d' category)

(international editor), e-mail jossch(at)nytimes.com; (888)
346-9867 or (212) 556-1927.

   AM-EARLY-FRONTPAGE-NYT _ Stories scheduled for Page 1 will be
